message_1: Let X be a compact connected topological space with the first cohomology group $H^1(X; \mathbb{Z}) \cong \mathbb{Z}/5\mathbb{Z}$. Suppose that there exists a continuous map $f : X \rightarrow S^1$ which induces an isomorphism on the first cohomology group with integer coefficients. What is the degree of this map $f$?
message_2:
Since $f$ induces an isomorphism on the first cohomology group with integer coefficients, we have $f^*: H^1(S^1; \mathbb{Z}) \rightarrow H^1(X; \mathbb{Z})$ is an isomorphism. We know that $H^1(S^1; \mathbb{Z}) \cong \mathbb{Z}$, generated by the fundamental class $[\alpha]$ of the generator of the fundamental group of $S^1$. 

Now, let's consider the induced map $f^*$ on cohomology. Since $f^*$ is an isomorphism, there exists an integer $n$ such that $f^*([\alpha]) = n \cdot [x]$, where $[x]$ is the generator of $H^1(X; \mathbb{Z}) \cong \mathbb{Z}/5\mathbb{Z}$. 

The degree of the map $f$ is defined as the integer $n$ such that $f^*([\alpha]) = n \cdot [x]$. In this case, we have $n \cdot [x] \in H^1(X; \mathbb{Z}) \cong \mathbb{Z}/5\mathbb{Z}$. Since $[x]$ generates $\mathbb{Z}/5\mathbb{Z}$, the integer $n$ must be coprime to 5. Thus, the degree of the map $f$ is an integer $n$ such that $\gcd(n, 5) = 1$.
